title: 112_hr1326
content: The "Furthering International Nuclear Safety Act of 2011" aims to enhance international nuclear safety cooperation, support the Convention on Nuclear Safety, improve nuclear safety for countries with civilian nuclear power programs, and increase public access to nuclear safety information. The "Furthering International Nuclear Safety Act of 2011" defines "appropriate congressional committees" as specific committees in the Senate and House of Representatives and the term "Convention" as the Convention on Nuclear Safety. The "Furthering International Nuclear Safety Act of 2011" defines key terms related to the Convention on Nuclear Safety, including Convention, meeting, national report, party, and summary report. The "Furthering International Nuclear Safety Act of 2011" defines key terms related to the Convention on Nuclear Safety. United States efforts to further international nuclear safety are outlined in Section 4. The President directs the US delegate to the Convention on Nuclear Safety to use their influence to encourage parties to assess safety progress, increase public availability of national reports, and enhance dissemination of answers to questions. The IAEA supports the Convention by posting information online, providing assistance to prepare national reports, and improving nuclear safety. All countries with civilian nuclear programs should join the Convention and create standard practices. Parties are urged to cooperate on creating standard practices for sharing information on nuclear accidents and developing emergency response plans. Additionally, they should enhance cooperation on predicting earthquakes, tsunamis, and radiation dispersion from nuclear sites, with all information to be posted on the IAEA's website. The Secretary of State, along with other relevant US agencies, must submit a strategic plan for international nuclear safety cooperation within 180 days. Additionally, reports on this cooperation must be provided to congressional committees. The Secretary of State, in collaboration with other US agencies, must submit a report to congressional committees within 180 days after the first two summary reports of the Convention. The report should detail the progress in implementing the strategic plan for nuclear safety and address the significant concerns of the US government regarding global nuclear safety. The report required under paragraph (1) shall be submitted in unclassified form, with a possible classified annex. The United States delegate to the Convention must provide a report on achieving the actions outlined in section 4 to congressional committees within 180 days after the first two summary reports of the Convention.
